posts.name: Carter Ryba
posts.cooked: I was just wondering how many cameras would be able to be uses with photonvision before it starts becoming super laggy

posts.name: sam liu
posts.cooked: For orange PI and 480p30fps processing, about 4~5 cameras will have the CPU running at about 80% utilization.  But if you are willing to do some wiring and spend a little more money, Amazon.com: Beelink SER6 Gaming Mini PC, Ryzen 9 6900HX (up to 4.9GHz) Mini Computer… This can probably run 480p60fps processing for 10 cameras.

link_counts.title: Amazon.com: Beelink SER6 Gaming Mini PC, Ryzen 9 6900HX (up to 4.9GHz) Mini Computer, AMD Radeon 680M, 32GB DDR5 RAM + 1TB PCIe4.0x4 SSD, 4K Triple Displays, HDMI, DP, USB4, WiFi 6 : Electronics

posts.name: Tolga Erdem
posts.cooked: What is the difference between wiring the orange pi and wiring this mini computer?

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: This is incorrect, because it’s not just about CPU usage, it’s about total USB bandwidth.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
We used 2x cameras on our 2023 robot with an OrangePi5 (albeit at higher resolution/framerate) and we had to use a pair of 20k RPM server fans just to keep it cool. We did try adding a 3rd camera at one point but weren’t satisfied with the performance.

Ultimately the most of the issues we had with that solution ended up being with Photonvision itself, and not performance of the hardware, and we switched to Limelights for our 2024 robot as a result.

Of the teams we did see running decent custom vision setups that year, pretty much all of them were using 1x OrangePi5 per camera, and some even added an extra co-processor OrangePi with no camera just to handle all the telemetry calculations and take the load off of the RIO.

To your question regarding wiring, the main difference is that, in the case of that miniPC at least, it looks like you’ll need a 12v → 19v step-up adapter (and probably one with decent voltage regulation to account for sudden drops). OrangePi on the other hand takes 5v 3A USB-C, which is a lot easier to adapt IMO.

I’m not totally sold on the MiniPC solution to be honest, though I will admit we did play around with the idea of buying a mainboard for a gaming laptop (for under the $600 price limit), and using that as a processing solution, since you’d get dedicated graphics and a legal integrated battery (“part of a COTS computing device”) to avoid any issues with voltage drops you’d see with other solutions. Ultimately, as I mentioned above though, we were pretty sure our issues were software, not hardware.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
As others have indicated, the question is under specified

→ How many coprocessors are running photonvision? I assume 1, but not all teams assumed that. → What kind of coprocessor? Performance matters a lot here. → What else is running on the coprocessor? What does photon need to share resources with? → What kind of cameras? Cameras themselves can get laggy depending on type and settings, regardless of photonvision’s load. → How are the cameras connected? Coprocessors are limited by how many things can be plugged in, both by physical ports and by bandwidth. → How much lag is “super”? Or, as I’d say, “too much”? This depends on what you’re trying to use the output to do.

A lot of folks here made assumptions for these questions and answered, which hopefully gives some sample points. But, as you can see, there’s not a single answer to the question as written, it varies a lot based on how you turn those “knobs” I mentioned.

posts.name: sam liu
posts.cooked: You’re right, I forgot about that.  It would take 1920 (pixels) x 1080(pixels) x 3(RGB) x 60(FPS) = 350Mbps for each camera.  The USB 3.0 Bus on the MiniPC has a bandwidth of 5GBps, so there will be a little bit of a shortage.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
You want to get a more reliable buck boost that is more resilient to brownouts, and protects the PC in those situations. I’ve fried 2 PCs using lesser buck boosts.

I’ve had good luck using this one: High Efficiency 6-32V to 0.8-28V 150W Notebook car Power Supply Buck-Boost Battery Regulator Amazon.com

Grapple Robotics’ mitoCANdria also seems like a great option for this in the future.
